Given my aggressive profile, I want to ride the momentum rather than get cute contrarian.

results.title: Super Bowl LX: Seahawks-Patriots picks, key stats, predictions - ESPN
results.snippet: A Patriots defense that was ordinary during the regular season by advanced metrics has allowed just six explosives through three postseason games while playing a series of compromised, injury-impacted offenses. The Seahawks gave up 12 explosives to the Rams in the NFC Championship Game. They won that matchup because quarterback Sam Darnold responded to two months of middling football by playing one of the best games of his life.

Limit the Seahawks to field goals and maybe Maye wins the game with a couple of touchdowns. The problem with that philosophy is New England's red zone defense was one of its biggest weaknesses on either side of the ball.

decision.reasoning:
Seeing everyone‚Äôs full reasoning actually *sharpens* my main takeaway: the ‚ÄúSeattle is the better team‚Äù case is loud and well-supported (FPI #1 vs #10, #1 defense, heavy expert picks, line moved to SEA -4.5). But the key point is that **all of that is already in the price** at 68.9%.

What persuaded me most (and it‚Äôs hard to argue with) is the **sportsbook anchor**: SEA ~-230 / NE ~+190. When you de-vig that, you get something like **SEA ~66‚Äì67% / NE ~33‚Äì34%**. So at **68.9%**, the market is basically paying an extra ~2 points of ‚ÄúSeattle tax‚Äù for the same information everyone is repeating.

What didn‚Äôt persuade me: the more contrarian ‚ÄúPats are secretly favored / Seattle is only ~42%‚Äù takes‚Äîthose feel like narrative reach. But I *do* think the Pats upset path is real and under-discussed relative to the certainty vibe: **NE‚Äôs dropback passing profile is legitimately elite**, and in a one-game Super Bowl that‚Äôs exactly the kind of thing that can flip outcomes. Add in that late-cycle sentiment often brings **underdog ML buyback**, and I think the near-term price risk is more down than up from here.

Net: I‚Äôm fading the crowd *at this price*, not fading Seattle as a team.

results.title: Patriots hold first official practice of Super Bowl week, Drake Maye "feeling great" - CBS Boston
results.snippet: The New England Patriots officially practiced for the first time on Wednesday ahead of Super Bowl LX against the Seattle Seahawks. Among those on the field at Stanford University was quarterback Drake Maye, who was limited all of last week with a shoulder injury and missed Friday's session with an illness.

results.title: Super Bowl LX injury report: Updates on Drake Maye's right shoulder, Sam Darnold's oblique, more - CBS Sports
results.snippet: Seahawks: Seattle had perfect attendance at practice, but did have several players limited: Quarterback Sam Darnold (oblique), offensive tackle Charles Cross (foot), safety Nick Emmanwori (ankle), offensive tackle Josh Jones (ankle, knee), linebacker Demarcus Lawrence (rest), fullback Robbie Ouzts (neck), receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba (rest), and defensive end Leonard Williams (rest). Patriots: Linebacker Robert Spillane (ankle) did not practice on Wednesday due to an ankle injury. However, he did tell the Boston Herald earlier in the day that he's "100% confident" that he'll be able to play in Super Bowl LX. Meanwhile, linebacker Harold Landry (knee) and offensive tackle Thayer Munford Jr. were both limited with knee injuries. Maybe the most important development on the injury front for New England comes at quarterback as the team listed Drake Maye (right shoulder) as a full participant.

decision.reasoning: This is net Patriots-positive: Maye trending fully healthy + start confirmation is a real upgrade vs. any lingering ‚Äúshoulder/illness‚Äù doubt, while Seattle‚Äôs QB showing up limited (oblique) is the kind of late info that can swing confidence and betting sentiment. Weather is basically neutral. I‚Äôd expect the market to drift further toward Patriots as kickoff approaches (and especially if any warmup chatter reinforces Darnold limitation), so at 29.7% Seahawks the value is on NO.
